I like Portal and would give it a 4/5: Here's why.
1. It can be buggy sometimes (I believe this is due to it being in the source engine and being very old, along with run on a newer PC, but IDK.)
2. It is pretty challenging.
3. It is 10 bucks.
Overall, I like Portal, but the main reason I got it, was so I could have some background to Portal 2. I will make a review for that game when I get it.

Last year, I played this 2007 classic for the first time.  It is a game I would honestly recommend to anyone over the age of 13 who has some facility with mouse and keyboard and enjoys solving puzzles. Even though it looks like an action game, it is more for puzzle game people than for action game people.  It does not require high skill, does not focus on combat, involves no loot, and has almost no character progression. 

Portal is better than any puzzle game before or since for three reasons. The basic mechanics of Portal create a sense of play that few games and even fewer puzzle games achieve.  Most puzzle games are all about the goal and the mechanics are just a means to that end, but even with no goal in mind, in Portal it is just fun to mess around with the portal gun.  Secondly,  even when there is only one solution to a given puzzle, the flexible design of Portal’s mechanics makes you feel like you are being creative.  Early in the game, it often doesn’t matter where you place “in” portal, which might make the decision feel arbitrary, meaningless, or too easy, but instead makes it feel personal, like the player is inventing their own “style” of puzzle solving.  Finally, very few puzzle games do the work of telling a story with their puzzles and those that do rarely tell a story as well as Portal.  The story begins as something that sounds contrived and built around puzzle gameplay, but it is told so playfully, with so much detail, and with such wonderful writing and voice acting that you follow along.  Then through story-based twists and turns the player has the sense of “escaping” the game, of taking control of their own fate, which dovetails perfectly with the sense of agency instilled by the game’s mechanics.
